title: Trump Says He's 'Very Disappointed' With Putin
description: US President Donald Trump said he was “very disappointed" with Vladimir Putin's behavior and left open the possibility of additional penalties over the war in Ukraine. Speaking to reporters in the Oval Office on Thursday, Trump left open the possibility of a one-on-one meeting with the Russian leader even if Putin hadn’t yet agreed to also sit down with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy. Bloomberg's Tony Halpin reports. (Source: Bloomberg)
content: Is your deadline still standing for Vladimir Putin to agree to a cease fire tomorrow or is that fluid now? It's going to be up to him and we're going to we're going to see what he has to say. It's going to be up to him very disappointed. For more, let's bring in Bloomberg's Tony Halpin out of Dubai. Morning, Tony. Happy Friday to you. We just heard from the president that he says that he could meet Putin soon, even without Zelensky. Is that a sign of more capitulation to come from the U.S. at this now bilateral meeting? Yes. Good morning. This is the Kremlin's ideal scenario that they want to get Putin in a room with Trump essentially alone without Zelensky in order to influence the US on an outcome that will be favorable to Russia. And clearly from a Ukrainian and European point of view, that would be very worrying indeed If Trump was willing to sit down with Putin to discuss an outcome in Ukraine that didn't include Ukraine, which of course is a very different position from his predecessor, Joe Biden, who famously said, you know, nothing about Ukraine without Ukraine. And in this situation, we'd have Putin and Trump sitting down together without Ukrainian presence, without a European presence to influence the U.S. thinking. And Russia will be able to present his view of the war and the view of any settlement without war. So that would be very much in Russia's interest. Well, yeah. You wonder if he'll make this concession whether what Trump would likely accept from Putin to drop secondary tariffs on buyers of Russian oil. Yes. As you've noted, today is the deadline. President Trump was very clear on what Putin had to do in order to avoid secondary sanctions, which was to agree to a truce by August the eighth. There's no sign at all that the Kremlin is willing to announce a truce, and so far at least, we believe that there's going to be a summit meeting between Trump and Putin without having first to concede such a truce. So it's very difficult in those circumstances for Ukraine and Europe to have confidence that Trump won't give away other things which they consider to be too too much of a concession. If he sits down with Mr. Putin without them present in the room. And then we've had Putin and the special envoy, Steve Wyckoff, also said to have discussed US-Russia relations at that meeting. How could they change? Yes. I mean, the whole Russian idea has been to try and develop bilateral relations with the US separately from resolving the war in Ukraine. They don't they don't think, in fact, that there is a resolution to the war which meets Russian demands and they want to continue fighting. But they also want to develop a good relationship with Trump because they want to build business relationships with the US and they see an opportunity to try and develop those bilateral relations separately with Trump and separately from any outcome in the war. And so again, the US, I think is entering a potential meeting with the Russians with perhaps a different view of that. They might still be trying to connect an outcome that resolves the war in Ukraine to developing relations between the US and Russia. But Russia views it very differently. They see those as two separate tracks.
summary: The deadline for Vladimir Putin to agree to a cease fire in Ukraine is still unclear, with President Trump stating that he is disappointed with Putin's lack of agreement on a ceasefire. The Kremlin hopes to have Putin and Trump alone alone to influence the US on an outcome favorable to Russia, particularly if they can discuss an outcome in Ukraine that excludes Ukraine. This move could signal a sign of more capitulation from the U.S. if it comes to an end to secondary sanctions, which Putin would likely accept from Putin to drop secondary tariffs on buyers of Russian oil. However, there is no sign at all that the Kremlin is willing to announce a truce, and so far, there's no sign of a summit meeting between Trump and Putin without having to concede such a truce. The Russian idea is to develop bilateral relations with the US separately from resolving the war in Ukraine and separately from any outcome in the war, but they see this as separate tracks.
shortSummary: President Trump is upset with Vladimir Putin for not agreeing to a cease fire, potentially benefiting Russia's interests in bilateral relations.
argos_summary: The article discusses the potential for a meeting between Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump, which could occur without Ukrainian President Zelensky present, raising concerns about U.S. concessions to Russia. Analysts suggest that this scenario aligns with Russia's interests, allowing them to influence U.S. policy without Ukrainian or European input. The article highlights the uncertainty surrounding a ceasefire deadline and the implications of a bilateral meeting that may prioritize U.S.-Russia relations over the resolution of the conflict in Ukraine.
